It was the poor-house, enlistment for foreign
wars and, when they protested, Peterloo. Both

1852.text:
the enforcement and the abandonment of market
crimes may today appear to be part of what

1858.text:
Alexander Bickel described as "the sediment
of history which is law" � but Bickel's

1863.text:
dismissive description overlooks the proactivity
of which law is also capable.

1870.text:
It's in the eighteenth century that you find
the foundations of two of the grandest of

1876.text:
the common law's edifices: the exclusion of
political ministers from the administration

1881.text:
of criminal justice, and the anathematisation
of slavery. The first of these was far from

1890.text:
being supported by clear-cut jurisprudence,
but Lord Camden's protean judgment in Entick

1895.text:
v Carrington became accepted � not unlike
Anisminic in the twentieth century � as

1900.text:
solid authority for what its audience wanted
to hear. The second, Lord Mansfield's holding

1906.text:
in Somersett's Case that the state of servitude
was unknown to the common law, was the exact

1912.text:
opposite: a perfectly clear-cut decision,
albeit extempore and brief, which ran into

1917.text:
a factitious morass of political, economic
and moral self-interest, some of it Mansfield's

1927.text:
The raid provoked by issue number 45 of Wilkes'
ferociously anti-government paper The North

1933.text:
Briton in April 1763 spawned a celebrated
clutch of lawsuits, principally against the

1939.text:
King's Messengers who had executed the Home
Secretary's general warrant to search for

1945.text:
and arrest the authors, printers and publishers
of the paper. These cases established that

1951.text:
ministers of the Crown had no judicial powers
as conservators of the peace; that the general

1956.text:
warrants they had been in the habit of issuing
were unlawful; and that they were answerable

1960.text:
to the ordinary courts for the consequent
trespasses committed by their agents.

1966.text:
It is probable that these decisions would
have had a lasting impact without the separate

1975.text:
lawsuit brought by John Entick, whose magazine
The Monitor had been raided late the year

1981.text:
before. But Entick bided his time and then
brought his own action against the King's

1986.text:
Messengers. Since the warrant used against
him had not been a general warrant, he limited

1992.text:
his claim to trespass to his house and goods;
but it turned out to be the opportunity that

1997.text:
Chief Justice Pratt (shortly to become Lord
Camden) had been waiting for to bring all

2002.text:
the issues of ministerial power together in
a researched and comprehensive judgment.

2009.text:
Pratt's judgment is a tour de force of legal
scholarship. In it he rebuts the claim, familiar

2016.text:
and more than once successful in the course
of the 17th century, that the state could

2022.text: commit wrongs under a shield of necessity:

2025.text:
"[W]ith respect to the argument from state
necessity, or a distinction that has been

2030.text:
aimed at between state offences and others,
the common law does not understand that kind

2035.text:
of reasoning, nor do our books take notice
of such distinctions."

2041.text:
This being so, ministers enjoyed no extra-judicial
powers of arrest or seizure. But did they

2047.text:
possess judicial powers to investigate and
suppress sedition, so that both they and their

2053.text:
officers enjoyed the same statutory protection
as constables whatever the outcome of their

2062.text:
The problem, as Pratt was compelled to acknowledge,
was that there was clear authority to the

2067.text:
contrary - the decision of Chief Justice Holt
in 1696 that the monarch's secretaries of

2073.text:
state possessed general powers of committal
� that is, arrest � as conservators of

2078.text:
the peace. The case had been treated as sound
law and followed in at least two subsequent

2084.text:
"I � am satisfied," said Pratt, "that the
secretary of state hath assumed this power

2089.text:
as a transfer, I know not how, of the royal
authority to himself; and that the common

2094.text:
law of England knows no such magistrate. At
the same time I declare, wherein my brothers

2100.text:
do all agree with me, that we are bound to
adhere to the determination of the Queen against

2107.text:
Derby and the King against Earbury; and I
have no right to overturn these decisions,

2111.text:
even though it should be admitted, that the
practice, which has subsisted since the Revolution,

2116.text: has been erroneous in its commencement."

2117.text:
There is something Denningesque about Pratt's
candid acknowledgment of contrary authority

2125.text:
and his equally candid refusal to follow it.
It might be possible by the use of advanced

2132.text:
casuistry to find a thread of consistent jurisprudence
in the passage, but history has not bothered

2138.text:
with this. It has taken the Court of Common
Pleas to have brushed aside the authority

2144.text:
of the King's Bench � a court of co-ordinate
jurisdiction with the Common Pleas and therefore

2150.text:
not able formally to bind it - and to have
laid down a bright line segregating criminal

2156.text:
justice from political governance. It is a
line which in recent decades has come under

2161.text:
growing stress (a stress first scrutinised
half a century ago by David Williams) with

2167.text:
the statutory enlargement of ministerial powers
of investigation and control. But when in

2175.text:
1993 the Crown in M v Home Office argued that,
as a minister of the Crown, a Home Secretary

2180.text:
who had defied an order of the court was not
answerable in contempt for his conduct, the

2185.text:
rebuff delivered by the law lords was justifiably
described by Professor Wade as the most important

2191.text:
judicial decision for over 200 years � meaning,
as he more than once made clear, since Entick

2200.text:
Somersett's Case, decided by Mansfield seven
years after Pratt decided Entick v Carrington,

2206.text:
was in some ways an equal and opposite phenomenon.
Mansfield, an experienced politician and a

2213.text:
shrewd investor, was not an abolitionist.
Not long before he had told John Dunning,

2218.text:
counsel for the West African seaman Thomas
Lewis whose employer, Stapylton, had purported

2222.text:
to sell him into slavery in England, that
the legality of slavery would be best left

2229.text:
"for I would have all masters think them free,
and all Negroes think they were not�."

2236.text:
But Granville Sharp, who had prosecuted Stapylton
for kidnapping Lewis and secured a verdict

2242.text:
that Lewis had never been Stapylton's property,
would not let it rest there. In November 1771

2247.text:
he learned that a West African re-named James
Somersett was being held in irons aboard a

2254.text:
ship at anchor in the Thames, awaiting transportation
to Jamaica where he was to be sold. Within

2261.text:
two days Sharp had obtained from Mansfield
a writ of habeas corpus calling on the ship's

2265.text:
captain to justify Somersett's detention.
The widely held belief that Mansfield deliberately

2271.text:
delayed a hearing is incorrect: he adjourned
it once in the express hope of a settlement,

2276.text:
but in June 1772 he sat in banc and, with
his fellow judges, heard out the arguments.

2283.text:
Albeit under pressure of time, Granville Sharp
had been able to assemble a formidable team,

2289.text:
led by Serjeant Davy and Serjeant Glynn, with
a future chief justice of the Common Pleas,

2294.text:
James Mansfield, and the scholarly Francis
Hargrave as their juniors, all of them appearing

2299.text:
without fee; while the slave-owners bankrolling
the ship's captain had briefed Dunning, the

2304.text:
former solicitor-general who had appeared
on Hargrave's instructions for James Lewis

2309.text:
and who in his submissions acknowledged the
unpopularity of his cause and took refuge

2314.text: in his duty to his client.

2321.text:
Mansfield's judgment was not quite the rhetorical
tour de force that legend has made it. The

2328.text:
stirring line "The air of England has long
been too pure for a slave, and every man is

2333.text:
free who breathes it" was shoehorned in by
Lord Campbell when he came in the following

2338.text:
century to write his Life of Mansfield. But
what Mansfield did say, although inelegant,

2345.text:
"The state of slavery � is so odious that
nothing can be suffered to support it but

2352.text:
positive law. Whatever inconvenience therefore
may follow from a decision, I cannot say this

2358.text:
case is allowed or approved by the law of
England, and therefore the black must be discharged."

2364.text:
In other words, the return to writ had no
foundation in English law. As a commercial

2372.text:
lawyer Mansfield knew very well what the inconveniences
were that would follow from his judgment,

2377.text:
which had been given (it should not be forgotten)
with the assent of the other three judges

2381.text:
of the King's Bench. Not only would the 14,000
black men and women held in servitude in England

2387.text:
and Wales become instantly free; it was probable
that the same had to follow in all Britain's

2393.text:
ceded or conquered colonies, where � in
contrast to the settled colonies, as Mansfield

2398.text:
himself was to hold two years later � the
common law had direct force.

2403.text:
That this did not happen, and that instead
the judges, with Parliament's acquiescence,

2409.text:
continued for decades to endorse or at least
tolerate colonial slavery, is an embarrassing

2415.text:
example of the law's capacity for moral cowardice
in the face of political and economic pressure.

2423.text:
Many MPs had interests in slave plantations;
slaving voyages, in which many of them had

2429.text:
stakes, could return a profit of 2000 per
cent. Mansfield himself in the Zong case,

2435.text:
some eleven years after Somersett's Case,
unblinkingly treated jettisoned slaves as

2440.text:
insurable cargo. As late as 1827 Lord Stowell
held that a slave who had lived in Britain

2447.text:
and so had become free could be enslaved again
on her return to the West Indies. And as late

2454.text:
as 1860 the English courts were prepared to
enforce contracts for the sale of slaves in

2460.text:
Brazil. Although abolition bills were introduced
pretty well every year from 1782, it took

2465.text:
Parliament until 1807 to outlaw slave trading
and until 1833 to formally abolish colonial

2472.text:
slavery � the latter at a monumental price
in compensation to the slave-owners, raised

2478.text:
by taxes on goods which fell mostly on the
domestic working class. Not a penny was paid

2489.text:
Here too the law can be seen making its own
history, not in the simplistic sense that

2493.text:
as time goes by one decision or statute succeeds
another, but in the sense that the judges

2500.text:
from time to time, and not necessarily collusively,
determine what trajectory of the law is to

2505.text:
follow. If the trajectory followed by the
judges on the issue of slavery was hesitant

2511.text:
and unprincipled, it was not, as is frequently
suggested, because Mansfield's judgment had

2517.text:
been unclear or equivocal. It was the lawmakers
both on the bench (Mansfield himself among

2522.text: them) and in Parliament who equivocated.

2527.text:
Their pusillanimity contrasts with what followed
elsewhere in the Empire. Here, according to

2533.text:
Mansfield's own doctrine in Campbell v Hall,
the laws of ceded or conquered colonies were

2539.text:
required to conform to the fundamental principles
of the common law. Each of the American colonies

2546.text:
took the opportunity of the War of Independence
to legislate either to abolish or to institutionalise

2551.text:
slavery within its borders. But the practice
of slavery also came in question in Lower

2557.text:
Canada, which � unlike the settled American
colonies - had become a British possession

2563.text:
by conquest. A petition to the Canadian parliament
in 1799 asserted that slaves in Lower Canada

2573.text:
"imbibed a refractory and disobedient spirit
under pretext that no slavery exists in the

2580.text:
The petition went on to recite that the Canadian
court of King's Bench, plainly in reliance

2586.text:
on Somersett's Case and on Campbell v Hall,
had begun granting writs of habeas corpus

2591.text:
to liberate not only two runaway slaves who
had been apprehended but, as the chief justice

2598.text:
"every negro, indented apprentice and servant
who should be committed to gaol under the

2603.text: magistrates' warrant in the like cases."

2608.text:
Let me turn lastly to a quite different way
in which legal history is made: by treating

2618.text:
inconvenient events as simply not having happened.
It is one thing - and not a mere pretence

2626.text:
- to hold a measure to be devoid of legal
effect; quite another to treat a historical

2631.text:
legal fact as never having occurred. Yet that
is how my generation (and I suspect others

2638.text:
too) were taught legal history: our lecturer
at the Inns of Court School of Law stopped

2644.text:
at 1649 and moved directly to 1660 because
everything that had happened between those

2649.text: years was, he said, a legal nullity.

2654.text:
This was not one teacher's idiosyncrasy. In
1660, on the restoration of the monarchy after

2660.text:
18 years of republicanism, the public hangman
was ordered to make a bonfire in Westminster

2666.text:
Hall (safety regulations not being then quite
as stringent as they are now) of every copy

2673.text:
of a number of republican enactments, and
a search was ordered to be made for every

2678.text:
copy of "the traitorous writing called the
Instrument of Government".

2686.text:
The Instrument of Government, enacted in 1653,
was Britain's first and only written constitution.

2692.text:
Not only did the Protectorate which it created
foreshadow the American model of presidential

2697.text:
government, with a parliamentary override
of any measures promulgated by the Protector;

2703.text:
it was palpably the source of a number of
provisions of the Bill of Rights adopted 35

2707.text:
years later by another Parliament which, for
all its protestations of legitimacy, had once

2713.text:
again unseated a monarch and was setting its
own terms of governance. We all know that

2720.text:
the Bill of Rights in 1689 declared the regal
practice of suspending or dispensing with

2725.text:
laws enacted by Parliament, and the raising
of revenue without Parliament's authority,

2729.text:
to be illegal. How many of us know that 35
years earlier the Instrument of Government

2738.text:
"That the laws shall not be altered, suspended,
abrogated or repealed, nor any new law made,

2744.text:
nor any tax, charge or imposition laid upon
the people, but by common consent in Parliament�"

2751.text:
We all know that it was the Act of Settlement
that in 1701 created the secure tenure of

2756.text:
judicial office which still underpins the
separation of powers. Who knew that it was

2763.text:
in 1642 that the Long Parliament first extracted
this principle from Charles I, and in 1648

2770.text:
confirmed it by statute ? While many of us
were taught at school � inaccurately � that

2780.text:
the Puritans had abolished Christmas, none
of us as law students were told that in the

2785.text:
years of the Interregnum, Parliament had stopped
the use of Latin and French in the courts,

2790.text:
had instituted civil marriage, had transferred
the criminal, probate and divorce jurisdiction

2795.text:
of the ecclesiastical courts to temporal courts,
and had stopped the routine gaoling of debtors.

2801.text:
You will not discover any of this from the
statute book. The Statutes at Large stop short

2809.text:
in 1641, the year before Parliament, on the
eve of the Civil War, began to legislate without

2814.text:
royal assent. The next page is dated 1660,
"the twelfth year of the reign of our most

2822.text:
gracious sovereign lord Charles the Second".
It was not until 1911 that the Acts and Ordinances

2829.text:
of the Interregnum � the Civil War, the
Commonwealth and the Protectorate - were finally

2834.text:
There is more. Who knew that it was under
the Protectorate that the origins of a salaried

2840.text:
civil service were to be found? Or that it
was the criminal courts of the Commonwealth

2844.text:
which first recognised the privilege against
self-incrimination and stopped the use of

2849.text:
paid informers? Or that, as chief justice
of Munster in the 1650s, John Cooke, the Commonwealth's

2856.text:
former solicitor general, authorised his judges
to administer law and equity together, with

2864.text:
the result, Cromwell told Edmund Ludlow, that
the Munster courts were deciding more cases

2867.text:
in a week than Westminster Hall in a year?
Or that the law commission set up under Sir

2874.text:
Matthew Hale had drafted sixteen bills to
codify large areas of law and procedure, and

2881.text:
by the time it was dissolved in 1653 had on
its agenda the regulation of lawyers' fees;

2888.text:
a ban on MPs moonlighting as lawyers; the
establishment of small claims courts; abolition

2893.text:
of the sale of offices and of benefit of clergy;
public registries of deeds; the right of accused

2900.text:
persons to be defended by counsel, to give
evidence and to call witnesses; and (at Cromwell's

2908.text: instigation) modification of the death penalty.

2912.text:
These might perhaps have been written off
as foolish essays in doomed idealism, as irrelevant

2918.text:
to the modern legal world as the Witanagem�t,
were it not for the fact that almost every

2924.text:
reform of the Interregnum, although annulled
at the Restoration, has since become a reality.

2931.text:
In 1731 English was again made the language
of the law. A deeds registry was opened in

2938.text:
1703, and a land registry in 1875. Civil marriage
was reinstituted in 1836. The remarriage of

2947.text:
law and equity was finally solemnised by the
Judicature Acts of 1873-5. Between 1697 and

2957.text:
1898 criminal procedure slowly crept back
towards where it had been in the Interregnum.

2963.text:
And 313 years after Matthew Hale and his commissioners
first set about codifying and reforming the

2970.text:
law, England and Wales again acquired a standing
law commission. Only the refusal of Parliament

2976.text:
to stop its elected members taking other employment
while collecting their parliamentary salaries

2981.text: has proved unshakable both then and now.

2985.text:
If there is a moral to these heterogeneous
stories, it is, I suppose, that the law, like

2994.text:
other subcultures, has its own versions of
truth and habitually recasts itself in their

2999.text: image. The late Geoffrey Wilson wrote:

3003.text:
"The courts do not operate on the basis of
real history, the kind of history that is

3010.text:
vulnerable to or determined by historical
research. They operate on the basis of an

3015.text:
assumed, conventional, one might even say
consensual, history in which historical events

3021.text: and institutions often have a symbolic value."

3027.text:
These versions of history may derive, like
the jurisprudence derived from Anisminic,

3030.text:
from what lawyers perceive as the law's intrinsic
logic; though the larger history of the twentieth

3035.text:
century, which I have not had space here to
explore, suggests deeper reasons of which

3041.text:
the lawyers themselves may not have been wholly
conscious. They may derive from the opposite:

3047.text:
the law's fear, following a decision like
Somersett's Case, of what it has itself unleashed.

3053.text:
Here the judicial casuistry tends to be more
visible. They may be dictated more or less

3060.text:
overtly by changes in political and economic
philosophy, as happened both with the old

3065.text:
market crimes and with the perceived modern
need to crack down on gang violence; or more

3072.text:
subtly but more radically by the slow growth
of a newly autocratic mode of government,

3078.text:
like the one which provoked the great showdown
between the Hanoverian monarchy's judges and

3083.text:
its ministers over state necessity and personal
liberty.

3087.text:
Lastly, the law's version of truth may simply
be derived from a dominant historiography

3093.text:
in which there are good guys (royalists) and
bad guys (republicans), and it's not comfortable

3099.text:
to accept that history was in a great many
respects on the side of the latter. If so,

3105.text:
there may be something after all to be said
for reading yesterday through the lens of

3111.text:
today. But it would be naive simply to reverse
Leavis's aphorism and to say there's no such

3117.text:
thing as law, only legal history. What it
is possible to say - and I think Tom Bingham

3123.text:
would have agreed, though Dicey would not
- is that without history there is no law.
